title: Oilers drop second game to Blues this season in home opener loss | Hockey | Spor
text:
If this keeps up, those Farewell Season signs at Rexall Place will take on an entirely new meaning.
It’s way too early to suggest the campaign is in jeopardy or that there isn’t plenty of time left to fix what’s wrong with the Edmonton Oilers, but 0-4 is never a great way to start.
But that’s how the Oilers are starting this year after dropping the home opener in the final season at Rexall Place.
What was supposed to be an emotional and uplifting night full of adrenaline and memories was simply a frustrating extension of the winless three-game road trip that preceded it. There were some good parts, just not enough of them in a 4-2 loss to the St. Louis Blues.
“It was another good game, but a game where we’re just not good enough to beat them,” said Oilers centre Ryan Nugent-Hopkins.
“We had a lot of chances, we just couldn’t find ways to score. And on the defensive side we played solid for the most part, but there were little breakdowns that led to big breakdowns and good teams find a way to take advantage of that.”
The Blues have been taking advantage of Edmonton forever. They are now 19-2-1 against the Oilers in their last 22 meetings.
“We’ve been losing to St. Louis for five years now,” sighed Taylor Hall. “We’re going to have to find a way to beat the St. Louis’s, the LAs. It’s fine if we can beat some of the bottom feeders, that’s great, but if we’re going to make up any ground we have to beat these teams.”
They now head to Calgary and Vancouver for a back-to-back set on Saturday and Sunday, hoping to stop their bleeding before 0-4 turns into something that can’t be fixed.
“If we let it, it can get into our heads,” Nugent-Hopkins said of the pressure to get a win. “But we have to use it as motivation right now.
“We had a really good pre-season, we were feeling good coming into the season, I thought our first two games were really good. Same with tonight, we just weren’t good enough to win the games, but we can’t get frustrated with ourselves.
“We have to find ways to score and limit the big mistakes and try to stay positive.”
After a lukewarm and underwhelming opening ceremony, the Oilers scored first, on Lauri Korpikoski’s first as an Oiler at 1:36, but St. Louis scored the next three — Jori Lehtera in the first, Vladimir Tarasenko in the second and Paul Stastny to make it 3-1 early in the third.
Edmonton rallied from 3-1 in the third when Hall scored his first of the season at 13:23, but Blues winger Alex Steen put it away for good with 2:09 left in regulation.
Edmonton’s power play finished 0-for-5 for the second time in three games and has become an obvious area of concern. It’s doing more to lose momentum than create it.
“Sometimes the other team kills your power play, sometimes you kill your own,” said head coach Todd McLellan. “We had a combination of both.”
The Oilers might be 0-4, but Matt Hendricks says this isn’t like any of the four-game losing streaks he’s seen here in the past.
“Dallas was a real stinker, the type of game we played was like a lot of our hockey last season, unprepared, not ready to play,” he said. “Tonight wasn’t like that. We brought our energy. That’s a tough hockey team over there and we fought with them for the whole night.
“Three out of four games were pretty good hockey. We didn’t get the wins, but at the end of the day that’s the type of hockey that’s going to win more games than lose.”

GAME REVIEW
Blues 4, Oilers 2
Three Stars
1. Jordi Lehtera , Blues
Scored a goal and added an assist for St. Louis.
2. Alexander Steen , Blues
Set up a goal and scored another in the win.
3. Taylor Hall , Oilers
Scored his first goal of the season on an excellent individual effort.
Game Grades
Offence D
Defence D
Goaltending C
Power play D
Penalty kill A
Toughness B
Effort C
Why Oilers lost
They were worn down by a bigger Blues team who took control of the contest in the late stages of the second periods. The Blues did not give the Oilers room to utilize their speed, playing a sound game and keeping plenty of players behind the puck.
Big play
Off a draw, Taylor Hall gets to the puck first and slides it through the legs of Blues defenceman Colton Parayko on the way to the net. Hall is then able to lift the puck over goaltender Brian Elliott to pull the Oilers within one in the third period.
Big save
Blues goaltender Brian Elliott is able to kick out a pad on a quick shot from Oilers centre Ryan Nugent-Hopkins to keep Edmonton from taking the lead in the first period.
Up next
Oilers at Calgary Flames, Saturday (8 p.m.) Scotiabank Saddledome.
- Compiled by Derek Van Diest
